docs.title: Documentation Overview
docs.text: This directory contains comprehensive documentation for the Codebase Interface CLI tool.

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
• usage.md - Detailed CLI usage instructions with examples
  • configuration.md - Complete configuration reference
  • agents.md - Validation agents documentation
  • examples/ - Example configurations and use cases

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: For basic usage, see the main README.md in the project root. For detailed documentation, start with usage.md.

docs.title: Serving Documentation Locally
docs.text:
To serve this documentation locally for easy browsing:

# Serve documentation at http://localhost:8000
task docs:serve

# Or serve and open in browser automatically
task docs:open

This creates a local web server that makes it easy to navigate through all documentation files with proper formatting and links.

docs.title: Navigation Guide
docs.text:
1. New Users: Start with usage.md for comprehensive CLI usage
  2. Configuration: See configuration.md for YAML setup
  3. Extension Development: Review agents.md for validation logic
  4. Examples: Browse examples/ for real-world configurations

docs.title: Contributing to Documentation
docs.text:
When contributing to this project:

  • Update documentation alongside code changes
  • Add examples for new features
  • Keep usage instructions current with CLI changes
  • Follow the established documentation structure

docs.title: Validation Agents Documentation
docs.text: Detailed documentation of each validation agent, their behavior, and customization options.

docs.title: Agent Architecture
docs.text: Each validation agent implements the Agent interface and performs specific checks on a codebase. Agents return structured results with findings, scores, and status information.

docs.title: Agent Interface
docs.text:
type Agent interface {
    Validate(targetPath string, cfg *config.Config) (ValidationResult, error)
}

docs.title: Validation Result Structure
docs.text:
{
  "agent": "agent-name",
  "status": "pass|fail|warning",
  "score": 0.0-1.0,
  "findings": [
    {
      "type": "missing|present|invalid",
      "file": "filename",
      "message": "Description of finding",
      "severity": "critical|warning|info"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Essential Files Agent
docs.text: Purpose: Validates the presence and quality of fundamental project documentation files. Priority: Critical

docs.title: Validation Logic
docs.text:
The Essential Files Agent performs the following checks:

  1. README File: Looks for README.md, README.rst, readme.md, or readme.rst
  2. Contributing Guidelines: Checks for CONTRIBUTING.md
  3. Documentation Directory: Validates docs/ structure and content

docs.title: Scoring Algorithm
docs.text:
Score = (Present Required Files) / (Total Required Files)
  • Each required file contributes equally to the final score
  • Missing critical files result in "fail" status
  • All files present results in "pass" status

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    essential-files:
      enabled: true
      require_readme: true
      require_contributing: true
      require_docs_directory: true
      docs_requirements:
        require_usage_guide: true
        require_examples: true
        min_doc_files: 3

docs.title: README Files
docs.text:
The agent searches for README files in this order:

  1. README.md (preferred)
  2. README.rst (reStructuredText)
  3. readme.md (lowercase variant)
  4. readme.rst (lowercase reStructuredText)

docs.title: Documentation Directory
docs.text:
When require_docs_directory is enabled, the agent checks for:

  • docs/ directory exists
  • docs/README.md or docs/index.md (documentation index)
  • docs/usage.md (usage instructions) - if require_usage_guide: true
  • docs/examples/ directory - if require_examples: true

docs.title: README Quality Assessment
docs.text:
When a README file is found, the agent can perform quality checks:

validation:
  agents:
    essential-files:
      readme_quality:
        min_lines: 10          # Minimum number of lines
        require_description: true    # Must have description section
        require_installation: true   # Must have installation section
        require_usage: true         # Must have usage section
        check_badges: false         # Check for status badges

docs.title: Documentation Completeness
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    essential-files:
      docs_completeness:
        check_toc: true            # Table of contents in docs/README.md
        check_cross_references: true # Links between documentation files
        require_api_docs: true     # API documentation for libraries

docs.title: Custom File Patterns
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    essential-files:
      custom_files:
        - pattern: "LICENSE*"
          required: true
          description: "License file"
        - pattern: "CHANGELOG*"
          required: false
          description: "Changelog file"

docs.title: Minimal Project Structure
docs.text:
project/
├── README.md
├── CONTRIBUTING.md
└── docs/
    └── README.md

Result: ✅ PASS (Score: 1.0) - All essential files present

docs.title: Incomplete Project Structure
docs.text:
project/
└── README.md

Result: ❌ FAIL (Score: 0.33) - Missing CONTRIBUTING.md and docs/

docs.title: Git Configuration Agent
docs.text: Purpose: Validates Git configuration files that ensure consistent development environment. Priority: High

docs.title: Validation Logic
docs.text:
The Git Configuration Agent checks for:

  1. .gitignore: Prevents committing unwanted files
  2. .editorconfig: Ensures consistent coding styles
  3. .gitattributes: Defines file handling attributes (optional by default)

docs.title: Scoring Algorithm
docs.text:
Score = (Present Files + Weighted Optional Files) / (Total Required Files + Weighted Optional Files)
  • Required files have weight 1.0
  • Optional files have weight 0.5
  • Missing required files significantly impact score

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    git-configuration:
      enabled: true
      require_gitignore: true
      require_gitattributes: false  # Optional by default
      require_editorconfig: true
      validation_rules:
        gitignore_validation: true
        editorconfig_validation: true

docs.title: .gitignore Validation
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    git-configuration:
      gitignore_validation:
        check_language_specific: true
        detect_project_type: true    # Auto-detect from files
        required_patterns:
          go: ["*.exe", "*.test", "*.out", "vendor/"]
          node: ["node_modules/", "*.log", ".env"]
          python: ["__pycache__/", "*.pyc", ".venv/"]
          general: [".DS_Store", "Thumbs.db", "*.swp"]

docs.title: .editorconfig Validation
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    git-configuration:
      editorconfig_validation:
        require_root: true           # root = true declaration
        require_charset: true        # charset specification
        require_indent_style: true   # indent_style specification
        check_file_types: true       # File type sections

docs.title: .gitattributes Validation
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    git-configuration:
      gitattributes_validation:
        check_line_endings: true     # Text file line endings
        check_binary_files: true     # Binary file handling
        check_export_ignore: true    # Export ignore patterns

docs.title: Language-Specific Validation
docs.text:
The agent can detect project type and apply appropriate validation:

// Project type detection
func detectProjectType(targetPath string) []string {
    // Detects based on presence of:
    // - go.mod -> Go project
    // - package.json -> Node.js project  
    // - pyproject.toml/setup.py -> Python project
    // - etc.
}

docs.title: Well-Configured Git Setup
docs.text:
project/
├── .gitignore        # Language-appropriate ignore rules
├── .editorconfig     # Consistent code formatting
└── .gitattributes    # Line ending and binary file handling

Result: ✅ PASS (Score: 1.0) - All configuration files present and valid

docs.title: Minimal Git Setup
docs.text:
project/
├── .gitignore        # Basic ignore rules
└── .editorconfig     # Basic formatting rules

Result: ✅ PASS (Score: 0.83) - Required files present, optional .gitattributes missing

docs.title: Development Standards Agent
docs.text: Purpose: Validates development workflow standards including commit messages and branch naming. Priority: Medium

docs.title: Validation Logic
docs.text:
The Development Standards Agent performs these checks:

  1. Conventional Commits: Validates recent commit messages
  2. Branch Naming: Ensures current branch follows naming conventions
  3. Commit Quality: Assesses commit history quality

docs.title: Scoring Algorithm
docs.text:
Score = (Valid Commits / Total Commits Checked) * 0.7 + (Branch Naming Valid ? 0.3 : 0)
  • Commit history validation contributes 70% to score
  • Branch naming contributes 30% to score
  • Configurable thresholds for pass/fail determination

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    development-standards:
      enabled: true
      check_commit_history: true
      commit_history_depth: 10
      require_conventional_commits: true
      validation_threshold: 0.8      # 80% of commits must be valid
      branch_validation: true

docs.title: Standard Format
docs.text:
<type>[optional scope]: <description>

[optional body]

[optional footer(s)]

docs.title: Supported Types
docs.text:
Default conventional commit types:

  • feat: New features
  • fix: Bug fixes
  • docs: Documentation changes
  • style: Code formatting changes
  • refactor: Code refactoring
  • test: Test additions/modifications
  • chore: Build process or auxiliary tool changes
  • perf: Performance improvements
  • ci: Continuous integration changes
  • build: Build system changes
  • revert: Revert previous commits

docs.title: Custom Type Configuration
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    development-standards:
      conventional_commits:
        allowed_types:
          - "feat"
          - "fix"
          - "docs"
          - "custom"     # Project-specific type
        require_scope: true
        scopes:
          - "api"
          - "ui"
          - "backend"
        require_breaking_change_footer: true

docs.title: Default Patterns
docs.text:
^(feature|feat)/.+          # feature/description
^(fix|bugfix)/.+           # fix/description
^(hotfix|patch)/.+         # hotfix/description
^(release|rel)/.+          # release/version
^(docs|documentation)/.+   # docs/description
^(chore|task)/.+           # chore/description
^(main|master|develop|development)$  # Main branches

docs.title: Custom Pattern Configuration
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    development-standards:
      branch_naming:
        patterns:
          - "^epic/.+"           # Epic branches
          - "^spike/.+"          # Research spikes
          - "^prototype/.+"      # Prototypes
        case_sensitivity: false
        min_length: 5
        max_length: 80

docs.title: Quality Metrics
docs.text:
The agent analyzes commit history for:

  • Conventional format compliance
  • Commit message length
  • Frequency of fix vs feature commits
  • Breaking change indicators

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    development-standards:
      commit_analysis:
        min_message_length: 10
        max_message_length: 72      # First line
        check_breaking_changes: true
        ignore_merge_commits: true
        ignore_fixup_commits: true

docs.title: Git Integration
docs.text:
The agent uses Git commands to gather information:

# Get commit history
git log --oneline -<depth>

# Get current branch
git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD

# Check if in git repository
git rev-parse --git-dir

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Common scenarios and handling:

  • Not a Git repository: Warning with graceful degradation
  • No commits: Skip commit validation
  • Git not available: Warning and skip git-based checks

docs.title: Well-Managed Repository
docs.text:
$ git log --oneline -5
abc1234 feat(api): add user authentication endpoint
def5678 fix(ui): resolve login form validation
ghi9012 docs: update API documentation
jkl3456 test(auth): add integration tests
mno7890 chore(deps): update dependencies

Current branch: feature/user-authentication

Result: ✅ PASS (Score: 1.0) - All commits follow conventions, branch naming correct

docs.title: Legacy Repository
docs.text:
$ git log --oneline -5
abc1234 Fixed bug in login
def5678 Added new feature
ghi9012 Update README
jkl3456 WIP
mno7890 Cleanup

Current branch: develop

Result: ❌ FAIL (Score: 0.3) - No commits follow conventional format, branch naming acceptable

docs.title: Custom Agents
docs.text:
Implement the Agent interface to create custom validation:

type CustomAgent struct{}

func (a *CustomAgent) Validate(targetPath string, cfg *config.Config) (ValidationResult, error) {
    // Custom validation logic
    return ValidationResult{
        Agent:    "custom-agent",
        Status:   "pass",
        Score:    1.0,
        Findings: []Finding{},
    }, nil
}

docs.title: Agent Registration
docs.text:
registry := agents.NewRegistry()
registry.Register("custom-agent", &CustomAgent{})

docs.title: Plugin System (Future)
docs.text:
Future versions may support plugin-based agents:

validation:
  plugins:
    - name: "security-agent"
      path: "./plugins/security.so"
      config:
        scan_dependencies: true
        check_secrets: true

docs.title: Agent Configuration
docs.text:
1. Start Simple: Begin with default configurations
  2. Iterative Improvement: Gradually increase validation strictness
  3. Team Consensus: Ensure all team members agree on standards
  4. Environment-Specific: Use different configurations for different environments

docs.title: Performance Optimization
docs.text:
1. Limit Commit History Depth: Use reasonable commit_history_depth values
  2. Disable Expensive Checks: Turn off quality checks for large repositories
  3. Cache Results: Consider caching validation results for CI/CD

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
1. Use JSON Output: For detailed debugging information
  2. Enable Verbose Mode: When available, for additional context
  3. Check Git Configuration: Ensure Git is properly configured
  4. Validate Configuration: Test configuration changes incrementally

docs.title: Configuration Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for configuring the Codebase Interface CLI tool via the .codebase-validation.yml file.

docs.title: Configuration File Location
docs.text:
The CLI looks for configuration in the following order:

  1. .codebase-validation.yml in the target directory (specified by --path)
  2. If no file is found, default configuration is used

docs.title: Configuration Structure
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    essential-files:
      enabled: true
      require_readme: true
      require_contributing: true
      require_docs_directory: true

    git-configuration:
      enabled: true
      require_gitignore: true
      require_gitattributes: false
      require_editorconfig: true

    development-standards:
      enabled: true
      check_commit_history: true
      commit_history_depth: 10
      require_conventional_commits: true
      branch_naming_patterns:
        - "^(feature|feat)/.+"
        - "^(fix|bugfix)/.+"
        - "^(hotfix|patch)/.+"
        - "^(docs|documentation)/.+"
        - "^(chore|task)/.+"
        - "^(main|master|develop|development)$"

  output:
    format: "table"  # json, table
    verbose: false

docs.title: Essential Files Agent
docs.text:

Setting Type Default Description enabled boolean true Enable/disable the agent require_readme boolean true Require README.md or README.rst require_contributing boolean true Require CONTRIBUTING.md require_docs_directory boolean true Require docs/ directory with usage documentation

docs.title: Conventional Commits Configuration
docs.text:
validation:
  agents:
    development-standards:
      require_conventional_commits: true

        allowed_types:

docs.title: Configuration Validation
docs.text:
The CLI validates the configuration file itself:

  • YAML syntax validation
  • Required field validation
  • Type checking
  • Range validation for numeric values

Invalid configuration will result in an error with specific details about the issue.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Version Control: Always commit your .codebase-validation.yml file
  2. Documentation: Document any custom configuration decisions
  3. Environment-Specific: Use different configurations for different environments
  4. Gradual Adoption: Start with minimal validation and gradually increase strictness
  5. Team Alignment: Ensure all team members agree on validation rules

docs.title: From Default to Custom Configuration
docs.text:
1. Run with default settings to see current validation status
  2. Create .codebase-validation.yml with default values
  3. Gradually customize settings based on project needs
  4. Test configuration changes thoroughly

docs.title: Updating Configuration
docs.text:
When updating configuration:

  1. Test changes locally first
  2. Update documentation if validation behavior changes
  3. Communicate changes to team members
  4. Consider backward compatibility

docs.title: Invalid YAML Syntax
docs.text:
Error: failed to parse config file: yaml: line 5: found character that cannot start any token

Solution: Validate YAML syntax using an online YAML validator or CLI tool.

docs.title: Unknown Configuration Keys
docs.text:
Warning: unknown configuration key 'validation.agents.unknown-agent'

Solution: Remove unknown keys or check for typos in agent names.

docs.title: Invalid Values
docs.text:
Error: commit_history_depth must be a positive integer, got: -5

Solution: Ensure numeric values are within valid ranges.

docs.title: CLI Usage Guide
docs.text: Comprehensive guide for using the Codebase Interface CLI tool.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Go 1.21 or later
  • Git (for development standards validation)

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/codebase-interface/cli.git
cd cli
go build -o bin/codebase-cli ./cmd/codebase-cli

docs.title: Installing Locally
docs.text:
# Build and install to $GOPATH/bin
go install ./cmd/codebase-cli

# Or using Taskfile (if available)
task install

docs.title: codebase-cli validate
docs.text: The primary command for validating codebase structure and standards.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# Validate current directory
codebase-cli validate

# Validate specific directory
codebase-cli validate --path /path/to/project

# Validate with JSON output
codebase-cli validate --output json

# Validate specific agent only
codebase-cli validate --agent essential-files

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Short Description Default --path -p Path to the project directory to validate . (current directory) --output -o Output format (table or json) table --agent -a Run specific validation agent (all enabled agents) --help -h Show help for the command

docs.title: Available Agents
docs.text:
• essential-files - Validates README.md, CONTRIBUTING.md, and docs/ structure
  • git-configuration - Validates .gitignore, .editorconfig, .gitattributes
  • development-standards - Validates conventional commits and branch naming

docs.title: codebase-cli version
docs.text:
Display version information.

codebase-cli version
# Output: codebase-cli v0.1.0

docs.title: codebase-cli help
docs.text:
Display help information for any command.

# General help
codebase-cli help

# Help for specific command
codebase-cli help validate

docs.title: Table Format (Default)
docs.text:
Provides a human-readable, styled output with colors and symbols:

✓ Essential Files Agent - PASS (Score: 1.0)
  ✓ README.md present
  ✓ CONTRIBUTING.md present
  ✓ docs/ directory structure present

✗ Git Configuration Agent - FAIL (Score: 0.5)
  ✓ .gitignore present
  ✗ .editorconfig missing

Overall Score: 0.75 - PASS (with warnings)

docs.title: JSON Format
docs.text:
Provides structured output suitable for programmatic processing:

[
  {
    "agent": "essential-files",
    "status": "pass",
    "score": 1.0,
    "findings": [
      {
        "type": "present",
        "file": "README.md",
        "message": "README.md present",
        "severity": "info"
      }
    ]
  }
]

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text:
The CLI uses standard exit codes to indicate validation results:

  • 0 - All validations passed successfully
  • 1 - Critical validations failed (missing required files, etc.)
  • 2 - Warnings present but no critical failures

docs.title: Basic Project Validation
docs.text:
# Navigate to your project
cd /path/to/my-project

# Run validation
codebase-cli validate

# Expected output for a well-structured project:
✓ Essential Files Agent - PASS (Score: 1.0)
  ✓ README.md present
  ✓ CONTRIBUTING.md present

✓ Git Configuration Agent - PASS (Score: 1.0)
  ✓ .gitignore present
  ✓ .editorconfig present

✓ Development Standards Agent - PASS (Score: 1.0)
  ✓ Recent commits follow conventional format
  ✓ Branch naming follows conventions: feature/new-validation

Overall Score: 1.00 - PASS

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
Use JSON output for automated processing in CI/CD pipelines:

# Generate JSON report
codebase-cli validate --output json > validation-report.json

# Example CI script
#!/bin/bash
if codebase-cli validate --output json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
    echo "✅ Codebase validation passed"
    exit 0
else
    echo "❌ Codebase validation failed"
    codebase-cli validate --output json
    exit 1
fi

docs.title: Specific Agent Validation
docs.text:
# Check only essential files
codebase-cli validate --agent essential-files

# Check only Git configuration
codebase-cli validate --agent git-configuration

# Check only development standards
codebase-cli validate --agent development-standards

docs.title: Validation with Custom Configuration
docs.text:
# With custom config file in project root
codebase-cli validate

# The tool automatically looks for .codebase-validation.yml
# See configuration.md for details on customizing validation rules

docs.title: "Failed to check commit history"
docs.text:
This warning appears when the tool cannot access Git history:

  • Ensure you're in a Git repository
  • Verify Git is installed and accessible
  • Check that the repository has commits

docs.title: "Branch name doesn't follow conventions"
docs.text:
The development standards agent validates branch names against common patterns:

  • feature/description or feat/description
  • fix/description or bugfix/description
  • hotfix/description
  • docs/description
  • chore/description
  • main, master, develop, development

docs.title: Missing Configuration File
docs.text: If .codebase-validation.yml is not found, the tool uses default settings. Create a configuration file to customize validation rules (see configuration.md).

docs.title: Debug Information
docs.text:
For detailed output, use verbose mode (when available) or JSON output:

# JSON output shows all validation details
codebase-cli validate --output json | jq '.'

docs.title: Viewing Documentation Locally
docs.text:
For easy browsing of the complete documentation, you can serve it locally:

# Serve documentation at http://localhost:8000
task docs:serve

# Serve and automatically open in browser
task docs:open

# Check documentation for common issues
task docs:check

This provides a better reading experience with proper formatting, working links, and easy navigation between documentation files.

docs.title: Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
Add validation as a pre-commit hook:

# .git/hooks/pre-commit
#!/bin/bash
echo "Running codebase validation..."
if ! codebase-cli validate; then
    echo "❌ Codebase validation failed. Fix issues before committing."
    exit 1
fi
echo "✅ Codebase validation passed"

docs.title: IDE Integration
docs.text:
Many IDEs can be configured to run external tools. Configure your IDE to run:

codebase-cli validate --path ${PROJECT_DIR}

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
name: Validate Codebase
on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  validate:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-go@v4
        with:
          go-version: '1.21'
      - name: Build CLI
        run: go build -o codebase-cli ./cmd/codebase-cli
      - name: Validate Codebase
        run: ./codebase-cli validate

docs.title: Custom Project Paths
docs.text:
Validate multiple projects or specific subdirectories:

# Validate multiple projects
for project in project1 project2 project3; do
    echo "Validating $project..."
    codebase-cli validate --path "$project"
done

# Validate with custom config per project
codebase-cli validate --path ./backend
codebase-cli validate --path ./frontend

docs.title: Automated Reporting
docs.text:
Generate reports for compliance tracking:

#!/bin/bash
# Generate validation report with timestamp
timestamp=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S")
report_file="validation-report-${timestamp}.json"

codebase-cli validate --output json > "$report_file"
echo "Validation report saved to: $report_file"

# Upload to reporting system or send notifications
# Example: send to webhook, save to database, etc.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Copy any example configuration to your project root as .codebase-validation.yml and customize as needed:

# Copy basic configuration
cp docs/examples/basic.yml .codebase-validation.yml

# Copy and customize for your project
cp docs/examples/go-project.yml .codebase-validation.yml

docs.title: Contributing Examples
docs.text:
To contribute a new example configuration:

  1. Create a new .yml file in this directory
  2. Follow the naming convention: descriptive-name.yml
  3. Include comprehensive comments explaining the configuration choices
  4. Add an entry to this README with a brief description
  5. Test the configuration on a real project

docs.title: Example Structure
docs.text:
Each example should include:

# Brief description of the use case
# Target project type or team size
# Key features enabled/disabled

validation:
  agents:
    # Agent configurations with comments

  output:
    # Output preferences

  custom:
    # Any custom settings
